item.title: Hans-Dietrich Genscher, an Architect of German Reunification, Dies at 89
item.description: As the country that he helped create grew into a flourishing nation and a force in the European Union, Mr. Genscher became a living political legend.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG R. WHITNEY and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Hans-Dietrich Genscher at his home near Bonn, Germany, in 2014.

item.title: Construction Firm Charged in India Overpass Collapse
item.description: The police in Kolkata detained eight executives of the company that built the elevated highway, after at least 23 people died.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: The collapsed overpass in Kolkata, India, on Friday as rescue operations continued.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: A Time of Bullies
item.description: Last month American Jews cheered a demagogue. This is the wrong moment to forget.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Tesla Model 3 Orders Surge Even Before Its Unveiling
item.description: The new electric vehicle is “the final step in the master plan, which is a mass market, affordable car,” said Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Tesla’s Model 3, a sleek five-seater, was unveiled at the company’s design studio in Hawthorne, Calif.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: How Hedge Funds Held Argentina for Ransom
item.description: By extracting a lavish settlement, U.S. vulture investors demonstrated how they could put a whole country’s recovery on hold.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN GUZMAN and JOSEPH E. STIGLITZ

item.title: Editorial: Hints of an End to the Fighting in Yemen
item.description: A cease-fire could lead to progress toward peace in a civil war that has become a proxy struggle over influence in the region.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: A Yemeni boy running past buildings damaged by air strikes in March.

item.title: Sinosphere: No April Fooling Please, We’re Chinese
item.description: A Chinese state news agency’s rejection of the West’s “Fools’ Day” received thousands of comments, and not everyone took the message seriously.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Chinese state news agency Xinhua warned against people using “Fools’ Day” to start or spread rumors online.

item.title: North Korea Tried to Jam GPS Signals Across Border, South Korea Says
item.description: The attempt did not disrupt any mobile communications or air or ship traffic, the South Korean government said, unlike previous efforts.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A North Korean soldier, right, looking at a South Korean counterpart through the window of a conference room at the truce village of Panmunjom, in the Demilitarized Zone between the two sides.

item.title: Janina Panasewicz, Seeker of Opportunity in Belgium, Died in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Ms. Panasewicz was part of a close-knit Polish expatriate community in the capital.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: Janina Panasewicz, 61, was killed at that Maelbeek subway station.

item.title: Berit Viktorsson, Visiting Daughter in Brussels, Was Killed in Attacks
item.description: Ms. Viktorsson, who was at the Brussels airport, had become adept at navigating the city on frequent trips to visit her daughter.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Berit Viktorsson was at the Brussels airport the day of the attacks.

item.title: Retired Rwanda Politician Dies While Jailed in Burundi as a Spy
item.description: Jacques Bihozagara’s death is under investigation at a time of escalating tensions between Burundi and Rwanda.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Suicide Bomber Strikes Cafe in Central Town
item.description: At least nine people were killed and 10 others wounded near a hotel in the town of Galkayo, a police official said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Judge Removed From Inquiry Into Ex-President
item.description: The Supreme Federal Tribunal’s decision, which is not its final ruling, transfers the inquiry into the finances of former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva to the high court from Judge Sérgio Moro.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Obama and President Xi of China Vow to Sign Paris Climate Accord Promptly
item.description: Officials cast the announcement as a statement of resolve by the world’s two largest greenhouse gas polluters, even though there are doubts about whether the United States can meet its obligations.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: President Obama with President Xi Jinping of China in Le Bourget, outside Paris, in November during the United Nations climate conference.

item.title: Starwood Bidding War Ends Abruptly, Yielding a Merger and a Puzzle
item.description: A consortium led by the Anbang Insurance Group of China withdrew its $14 billion offer with no explanation, clearing the way for Marriott’s offer.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and LESLIE PICKER
item.media:description: The W hotel in Los Angeles, owned by Starwood. The merger of Starwood and Marriott will create the biggest hotel company in the world.

item.title: As Obama Hosts Nuclear Security Summit, the Focus Is on China
item.description: More than 50 world leaders met in Washington, where President Obama and President Xi Jinping found unity on climate change but tension over disputed waters.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama met with President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, left, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan on the sidelines of the nuclear security summit on Thursday in Washington.

item.title: Editorial: The Danger of a Runaway Antarctica
item.description: Despite environmental progress, the threat of rising seas must be countered by increased international cooperation and leadership from the United States.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: View From Space Hints at a New Viking Site in North America
item.description: The site was identified last summer after satellite images showed possible man-made shapes under discolored vegetation on the Newfoundland coast.
item.dc:creator: RALPH BLUMENTHAL
item.media:description: Douglas Bolender, left, and Sarah H. Parcak, right, looking for evidence of a Viking presence in Point Rosie, Newfoundland. If confirmed, the site would be the second known Viking settlement in North America.

item.title: Zaha Hadid, Groundbreaking Architect, Dies at 65
item.description: Ms. Hadid, the first woman to win the Pritzker Prize, was renowned for her theoretical work that left a mark on skylines around the world.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL KIMMELMAN
item.media:credit: Steve Forrest for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zaha Hadid in her London apartment in 2008.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Syrian Refugee’s Message to the European Union
item.description: We fled war to find safety with our families. Why is the E.U. making our lives more miserable?
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LAILA
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laila and her sons at the Idomeni refugee camp in Greece on Wednesday.
